results.title: [Agnotes Advertisement: 4]
results.brief_description:
Victoria’s Department of Agriculture (now Agriculture Victoria) produced Agnotes, a series of reference material for the industry with the aim to disseminate expert advise for best agricultural practices.

This advertisement was designed to increase the uptake of the Agnotes by farmers. It is one of many commercials produced for the Department of Agriculture.

results.title: [Adam Tsaktserlis]
results.brief_description:
A passenger on the Murray River Queen gets into trouble when he falls off the ship and seemingly gets eaten by a large fish. Subsequently, the steamer loses oil which drips into the sea.

An animated short entered to “Create a Stamp Story” section of ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: [Accident service]
results.brief_description: The new conception of rehabilitation is shown through the study of the methods (circa 1945) used in treating and caring for injured miners at a well-known hospital and rehabilitation centre in the English Midlands. All stages of treatment are presented. Interesting from a historical viewpoint. NB: Contains some graphic images.

results.title: [ABC TV News: First Bulletin in Colour for 1st March, 1975]
results.brief_description:
Nearly 19 years after he presented the first ever ABC TV nightly news bulletin (on 5th November, 1956) newsreader James Dibble presents the first ever ABC TV news bulletin in colour.

In this bulletin, the news includes coverage of a serious rail accident in the London underground, ongoing conflict in Cambodia, and French nuclear testing in the South Pacific. A young Jeff McMullen investigates the U.S. amnesty program for draft resisters and deserters; while Jim Revitt reports on the progress of Darwin’s recovery following Cyclone Tracy.
results.title_for_label: [ABC TV News: First Bulletin in Colour for 1st March, 1975]

results.title: [ABC TV News: Bulletin for 11th March, 1958]
results.brief_description:
The first ABC TV nightly news bulletin was broadcast on 5th November, 1956. The newsreader, James Dibble, went on to present the ABC TV News in Sydney for 27 years; his last bulletin was on June 10, 1983.

When television arrived in Australia the ABC Commissioners were concerned that pictures might trivialise the news and decided that no more than two minutes of film should be included in a 15-minute bulletin. This early news bulletin (from 1958) conforms to this rather stilted style of presentation considered appropriate by the ABC. The minimal use of graphics and live news footage, as well as the newsreader’s accent, are in striking contrast to the way news and current affairs have been presented on television in the decades since the 1950s.

In this bulletin, the news includes reports of conflict between the Indonesian government and Sumatran rebels, an Australian High Court taxation law ruling, cleaning-up after a big storm in Sydney, the discovery of a World War II mass grave in Poland, elections in Sudan, and a report on the state of the international television industry in 1957.
